intro: i'll come up with a good meme to put here later

post.body: where did all these meme accounts come from all of a sudden
been off here for a while; any good anarchist sites pop up in the last few months?
Posted a short writeup on how to get ZeroNet and Tor working on NixOS on my new blog: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NwLRktTUXSbaQUeQmSihmxtEuopLHTp39/?Post:2:Zeronet+over+Tor+on+NixOS

comment.body: In chromium 60 on arch, the site tries to call `xdg-open`, which results in 2 new windows with only the new tab in each. Going to http://zero/ URLs manually works correctly.
actually, after i restarted chrome a couple times, I got it to respect the .pac at all times. Now I just gotta get it to respect zero:// links

and it's working! the relevant files are here:
http://zero/17iF64gTLycSohUSJsFyq7FMYsQfMqghJa/?1JupR9ExhM4aiVd1Jyy2iuS12eukDnQ54X_0
http://zero/17iF64gTLycSohUSJsFyq7FMYsQfMqghJa/?1JupR9ExhM4aiVd1Jyy2iuS12eukDnQ54X_1
@leftside: bit of a late reply to this post, but basically that just means they wont have a copy on their machine. it stays on the machines of everyone who's downloaded it before
@leftside: they just have different settings, and different people who are able to edit the settings. no real difference beyond that
@leftside: no; each hub only has whatever data has been added to that particular hub. i meant from a user's perspective they all function the same way, except for the admin and a few settings tweaks.

@leftside: in my understanding, admins only have control of certain parts of a zite. any user data (data signed by a user's private key) is untouchable for them. the best they can do is hide it, but even then the data still exists.

if by delete the zite, you mean that he removes it from his computer, then the zite still exists as is, just not his copy. if you mean he vandalizes it so none of the posts can be seen, then ye, the data should still be recoverable. in either case, the admin is unable to destroy user data in any meaningful way
@leftside: correct. a user's data.json can only be changed by someone with that user's private key, but the actual zite itself is still under the admin's control
@leftside: each user chooses which hub they want to keep their data on. if you exclude a certain hub from your site list, the only effect is that you dont see data from that hub.
@leftside: yeah, the posts of people on hubs you dont have downloaded wont show up for you. you can always just install those hubs tho if you want to see their posts
@leftside: exactly. it solves the problem of extremely large zites by breaking up the content into more reasonable chunks
@leftside: yep, exactly. they don't solve the problem perfectly since there's no way to enforce the splitting (everyone _could_ all join just one hub), but in practice it works pretty well

@leftside: you can submit an issue with this link: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/new

and i really like the time-based slicing idea; it sounds super useful for low-storage/low-bandwith clients!
